Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2010 08:00PM Kim09 wrote: I went through the same thing.  My first clue that is was going to be painful was the nurse saying as she is wheeling me into the injection room saying "I am so sorry but this is going to really hurt".

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 08:22PM Kim09 wrote: Liz, If you want to take a painkiller try tylenol.  I was allowed to take that when I couldn't take aspiran a week before any procedures.
Posts.Title: MRI guided biopsies? liztaylor1 MTwoman

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2010 06:18PM Kim09 wrote: As others have said it is a personal matter regarding who you tell.  In my case, I told my immediate family and they took care of passing the news along.  That way everyone was aware but I wasn't having to deal with telling everybody.  For work I told my co-workers and let them know it was okay to let others know if they inquired.  I found out that there were a lot of co-workers who had gone through this and they were able to give me some good advice regarding how to handle some of the treatments.  It also helped that my bosses were very supportive. By being open about it I found it alot easier to deal with everyday life.  Normally I am a private person but for this I was a very open person. Just follow your instinct regarding who you tell.
Posts.Title: Who and when to tell? wyldblumusic Frapp

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2010 06:55PM Kim09 wrote: The MRI-guided biopsy is just like a stereotatic biopsy but it uses the MRI machine and instead of the Mamogram machine.  It is used when something is only seen with the MRI.  I had to have 3 done at one time and the all turned out to B9.  The MRI-guided biopsy was easier on my back then the stereotatic.  It is performed right there in the MRI room.  You are in the same position as when you had the original. I did take a valium right before to calm my nerves.
Posts.Title: MRI guided biopsies? liztaylor1 MTwoman

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2009 10:17PM Kim09 wrote: Katherine - You have to really stretch the drain lines to clear the fluid.  The only time you need to do that is if it looks like you have a clog in it.  The trick is to get a really good grip of the tubing with one hand and really squeeze and slide with the other stretching the tubing until it is flat.  I just had my bi-lat on November 30 and just got rid of the 3 remaining drains Tuesday.  Also are you keeping track on how much fluid is in the drains?  My surgeon had me doing this and when he saw that it was consistently draining at a certain level he pulled them.  When its time for them to come out I recommend you take some pain medicine because at least for me it was not a pleasant experience. Another recommendation is if you still have the drains and are trying to take a shower use a piece of ribbon or string around the waist to hold the drains.  I was able to start taking showers 5 days after surgery and found the ribbon helped.

Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2009 11:22PM Kim09 wrote: I ddin't drive until all my drains were out which was 2 weeks after surgery.  The way I dealt with the seatbelt was to wear my surgical camisole with the the "puffys" in place.  The camisole also came in handy when I had the drain because it had pockets to place them in.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2010 10:50PM Kim09 wrote: You could try appealing the decision.  The insurance company's appeal process is normally stated on the EOB's that they send you.  You also may want to check the clinical bulletin policies to see if they have one regarding this procedure.  They probably have them posted on their website.  If they do have one on this procedure you would want to refer to it in your appeal.
Posts.Title: Insurance doesn't want to pay precious1969 EstherMSKCC

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 04:56PM Kim09 wrote: M360 - Have you talked to an oncologist or surgeon yet?  They are the ones that will make the recommendations to you not your regular doctor.  Sometimes the chemo will be before the surgery, sometimes after and sometimes there is no chemo.  The oncologist or surgeon may be willing to start after the holidays or least explain why they feel you need to start right away.  Remember they can't force you to do anything you don't want.
Posts.Title: onco or breast surgeon..which visit first? PiscesMoon MaineCoonKitty

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2010 01:54PM Kim09 wrote: I would recommed going to your Insurance company's website and see if they have their clinical policy bulletins available.  Aetna has one regarding this matter.  It spells out what situations they will automatically allow the procedure.  I am sure most insurance company's have these bulletins.  Aetna did not give me any trouble about getting the surgery.
Posts.Title: Insurance Approval for BXM michelekb Kim09

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2010 10:11PM Kim09 wrote: Feroza - I am a little confused with your question about the port.  A surgeon put in my port.  The port can only be accessed by medical personnel and is usually used for your chemo drugs plus the other medications, blood draws and for iv's when you are admitted to the hospital.  The Neulasta shot is normally given the day after chemo.  My Neulasta shot was done at the cancer center and it was just given in my arm not my port. The Neulasta helps stimulate WBC growth.  In my case it was essential because the first treatment did not include it and I ended up in the hospital because my WBC's were way to low.
Posts.Title: neo-adjuvant chemo 1marmalade1 toni30

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2009 05:16PM Kim09 wrote: Not everyone has to get the Neulasta shot.  My onc's philosiphy is that he doesn't do it unless he has to.  So my first round I didn't get it.  Unfortunately my wbc's dtopped too far and I ended up in the hospital for a couple of days.  So after that I had a shot the day after each round.  Talk to your doctor about the Neulasta shot.  He is the one that has to order it.
Posts.Title: neo-adjuvant chemo 1marmalade1 toni30

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 05:49PM Kim09 wrote: Jude, You should check your insurance company's "Clinical Policies".  My insurance company "Aetna" had one for when a prophalatic mastectomy would be covered.  There were multiple situations that were covered including one where you if you were 45 or younger when diagnoised.  If your insurance company has a website you should be able to find a link to the policies.   Have you tried calling your insurance company and asking them directly?  I ask because it seems not all insurance companies work the same.  I have seen some woman have problems getting certain tests done and others have to fight with their insurance companies to get the same tests done.

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2010 07:50PM Kim09 wrote: Billynda - It depends on how your insurance works.  In my case the cancer center first bills Aetna.  Aetna then adjusts the bill to the agreed upon rate and lets the center know how much of it I am responsible for (deductible and copays) and how much they are responsible for.  So this is my long winded way of saying I did not have to pay each day but will get billed later.  Once I hit my maximum out-of-pocket for the year everything will be on Aetna's dime.
